So I did a research, 

In June 2016, Diamond moved 280,000 units of Batman 1 by king. Coming in at #2 that month. Civil War II 1 beat it.

3.author: WarWolf343
3.body:
Oh yeah, that's right. During the tail end of King's run things started to fall for *Batman*. I think it was a mix of people being tired of the same writer and feeling misled with the whole wedding not happening that led to it falling and King being kicked off the book. Can't believe I blanked on that. 

Same thing would happen towards the end of Slott's run as well, with *ASM* falling outside the top fifteen a few times. If a run is long enough, I think you will see reader fatigue start to kick in. But the moment a new writer comes in, you almost always see a jump in sales that last quite some time.   

However, it should be noted that by July of 2019 *Batman* was only behind *House of X* #1, *Powers of X* #1, *ASM* #25, *The Walking Dead*, and *Batman: The Last Knight on Earth*. #1s and #25s tend to sell very, very well, and iirc, *The Walking Dead* was reaching its endgame around that time, so it's sales improved, while *The Last Knight on Earth* was a mini by Snyder, so it was always going to sell well. Meanwhile, *Immortal Hulk* dropped from the 7 spot in June to the 20 spot. 

Books like *Batman* and *ASM* remain far more consistent than other books and always sell high numbers.   

Side note: it should be noted that *ICv2*'s methodology in inherently flawed. It uses a non randomized set of one hundred and twenty five stores, when they should be using three hundred randomized stores. But since DC and Marvel stopped using Diamond, we lost access to their sales data which means that *ICv2*'s numbers are all we got. So it is possible that other books frequently outsell *ASM* and *Batman*, but I think that list would be very short.     

For the most part, *ASM* and *Batman* remain in the top spots with the current data we have (and even with the Diamond data they were usually Marvel and DC's best selling books). With any luck, *ICv2* will be able to get access to more stores point of sale data for a more complete picture.

So, there's different types of collected editions 

Trade paperback (TPB) : soft cover volume that collects multiple issues 

Hardcover:  a TPB with a hardcover (lol)

Omnibus: it usually collects an entire run and includes some extras (sketches, interviews, variant covers, etc). The format is bigger and the paper quality is better too.

Deluxe edition: it has the same height and paper of an Omnibus but it doesn't collect the whole run, most of the times it's just a particular story or a part of a run. (It also includes extras)

Absolute: it's bigger (in height, not page count) than an Omnibus, it includes even more extras and has a better quality in both paper and spine.

34.author: Cyoarp
34.body:
Okay well unbelievably I don't see, "Sandman," on that list and I should. "Sandman," is amazing it was the first comic I ever read I loved it so much I I started reading comics which says something as I was pretty biased against comics at the time. "Sandman," is amazing. Another good one is, "Books Of Magic," read it after, "Sandman," not before.

It's a little bit more mainstream but I would also read, "Crisis On Infinite Earths," if you haven't already.

In fact I would read, "Sandman," and then, "Crisis On Infinite Earths," and then, "Books Of Magic." "Books Of Magic," is a spin-off of, "Sandman," they're both written by Neil Gaiman they are both amazing. "The Books Of Magic," does have a little bit more to do with DC Comics continuity however, and a good way to get to know the basics in one easy book is "Crisis On Infinite Earths."You by no means need to read, "Crisis On Infinite Earths," to enjoy either of the other two, but, 'Crisis,' is in and of itself incredibly good; probably one of the two best things to ever come out of DC Comics.(*not including vertigo*)


Some other must reads are the Grant Morrison runs of Animal Man and Doom Patrol.(Read the animal man ones first)

Oh! If you like, "Sweet Tooth," you will probably like, "Y- the Last Man."

Everyone else seems to really like the old, "Swamp Thing," runs, I personally have a lot of trouble getting into those, however, "Swamp Thing Vs. Batman," is truly good.

If you read, "Preacher," you'll like, "HellBlazer," which is a Constantine run. I'll admit I haven't read it yet but I do love Constantine and everyone keeps insisting that I read, "Hellblazer."

If you've made it this far I can also suggest, "Hitman." It's a little lighter than the other titles and it's another title where you'll probably want to know a little bit about the DC universe. It is a vertigo book though but Kyle Rainer is in it. This is the book where the section-8 team was introduced as well as the infamous anti-hero, The Dog Welder.(*though neither takes part heavily in the story*)

And last but not least but *definitely last*(*because if I had said it first I would have lost all credibility*) is "Marvel Zombies." Believe it or not this is a really good series. It starts off as a cheap misdirect filler miniseries in the ultimate universe turns into a weird crossover with the ape universe before finally becoming a filler series in the main universe. Even so it manages to be really good anyway. But after that it takes off in a big way basically becoming an anthology series... Starring alternately Howard The Duck or Robot Man.

And that's my list of what I think you'll like best. Obviously there are other more mainstream comics that I love but I think this list is what you're looking for.

58.author: ThreadbareHalo
58.body:
Xavier no longer believes human and mutants should coexist, he hides away from and routinely disparages his son, he never shows his face or teaches anymore and he’s often agreeing with the most covert and forceful actions when that used to be exact opposite of his bag.  Hell x-force works under his approval.

Batman refuses routinely to trust anyone despite each time he does that it backfires on him.  He creates surveillance systems that a 90s Batman would have been horrified by.  His more modern incarnations have become increasingly violent.  He’s depicted frequently as alone and miserable.

Forge has built armor out of living mutants without their consent.  He operates on xforce to kill people.

Mr fantastic created a prison in the negative zone for superheroes who didn’t register and makes plans for the whole world without their agreement in the Illuminati.

Like… I know these things are normal now but taking a step back… those are pretty consistent negative connotations associated with intelligence.  I agree the extremes aren’t good but there really aren’t that many good examples of intelligence in plot lines lately.  Hell the most recent crossover of judgement day had tony stark almost killing every human on earth because of something he smartly thought up and intelligence didn’t fix it.
